wahangagakere: I read an article of ‘social etiquette’ written a couple of years back by a self identifying cis-man about how disgusting armpit hair (and armpit stubble is) on women and t(his) voice was always in my head whenever I had a few little strands growing. mariaemanuelamargraf: When I was born my body already started to set free hair growth hormones, so at the age of 1 i already had hair all over my body. With all these hairless women shown in media I felt like my body is disgusting and will never be loved because of my hair. But now, thanks to this great wave of feminism, I realized, that I don’t have to give a single damn. Either u like my hair or don’t( there is no logical reason to hate someone’s body hair) but for me these are the plants that grow on my body. So thank u for posting this helping me and a lot of young girls and boys to love and accept their hair . <3

nabilasawakeningdream: Though I’ve dated mostly women, perhaps due to grooming etc, I never really knew what was meant by ‘bikini line’. I thought it was maybe like a stray few hairs here and there because that’s all I ever got and all I ever saw. Now dating my current girlfriend, she’s pointed out her own pubic hair growth and been more comfortable around me with it. I finally saw what was meant by ‘bikini line’ for the first time a couple weeks ago. I legitimately said to her, “is this what you meant? I’m so fascinated”. I find it so crazy I’m turning 30 and I never knew. But how would I if I’d never seen it before? So, thank you for putting this picture out there and taking steps to normalising body hair (and ALL kinds of it). ✨
